Build against the internal libc++ for proper cfi-icall and cfi-icast protection. This also builds libcxx with CFI, Full RELRO, noexecstack, SSP security features. This is the upstream default.

Use CET for hardware accelerated execution integrity checks.
For official builds, utilize CET protection in the V8 JavaScript engine.
For unofficial builds, increase the CET protection coverage as much as possible.
(EXPERIMENTAL)

Use software based execution integrity checks.
Builds with mitigations to ensure execution integrity within built code. Mitigates against unauthorized transactions or actions from the compromised execution integrity by crashing the process before running attacker's code.
| CF edge type | Estimated performance slowdown | Mitigated attack vectors | Attack difficulty | Report prevalence | Programming equivalent cfi-cast | - | 1.01 - 1.05 | CE | Medium | Most | dynamic_cast in C++ cfi-icall | forward | 1.05 - 1.10 | CE, PE | Medium | Moderate | Function pointer call in C or C++ cfi-vcall | forward | 1.05 - 1.15 | CE, PE | Easy | Most | Virtual function call in C++ shadow-call-stack | backward | 1.01 - 1.03 | CE, PE | Hard | Least | Function return in C or C++
CE = Arbitrary Code Execution PE = Privilege Escalation
PE is mitigated in SUID builds.
Arm64 users, see also the cpu_flags_arm_pac, cpu_flags_arm_bti USE flags.
Additional ebuild per-package environment variables if USE=-official:
USE_CFI_ICALL - 1 to enable, 0 to disable cfi-icall USE_CFI_CAST - 1 to enable, 0 to disable cfi-cast
For the official build settings, it is fixed based on the ABI.
The build defaults for CFI are as follows:
For x86-64, it will use cfi-vcall=true, cfi-icall=true, cfi-cast=false For all other microarches, are all false, but you may customize via the -fsanitize= compiler flag with the cfi USE flag.
The CFI sanitizer can mitigate only a few top 50 reported vulnerabilities.

Use GWP-ASan to mitigate against memory corruption (Use After Free, Heap Overflows, Buffer Overflows, Use After Return) for undiscovered critical-high severity vulnerabilities. When memory corruption is detected, the process will crash to prevent attacker's code being executed. (EXPERIMENTAL)
It requires manual changes to the wrapper. This may slow down the build by 2.5x worst case.
It is primarily used as a debug tool but not recommended in production by sanitizer developers due to the performance penalty or the performance-first security posture.
Hardened users may want to enable this option for added real-time protection.
The GWP-ASan sanitizer can mitigate many of the top 50 reported vulnerabilities.
Note not all heap allocations are checked. The sampling rate is about 1:10000, 1 check out of 10000 allocations or 0.1% of all allocations total inspected for memory corruption.
